sections.title: 1. In\froduc\fion
paragraphs: Speech models based in \fhe separa\fion of \fhe periodic and \fhe noise\blike par\fs of \fhe speech were early in\froduced in \fhe speech processing panorama. The early work by McAulay and Qua\fiery (1986) wi\fh \fhe sinusoidal modelling, where \fhe signal was modelled by means of sinusoidal componen\fs loca\fed a\f \fhe frequencies where \fhe peaks of \fhe spec\frum were, was quickly followed by \fhe harmonic sys\fems (Griffin & Lim, 1988; Laroche, S\fylianou, & Moulines, 1993; S\fylianou, 1996). This harmonic cons\frain\f is appropria\fe for \fhe speech signal and simplified \fhe analysis and \fhe syn\fhesis, elimina\fing \fhe need of peak picking and peak \fracking algori\fhms. However, modelling only \fhe harmonic par\f of \fhe signal leaves ou\f qui\fe a lo\f of informa\fion, so harmonic models were complemen\fed wi\fh a noise\blike componen\f. This noisy componen\f has been defined in differen\f ways: some proposals (Laroche, S\fylianou & Moulines 1993; S\fylianou, 1996) assume \fha\f \fhe noise is above a cer\fain frequency (harmonic plus noise family, HNM); o\fhers overlap \fhe harmonic and \fhe noise\blike par\fs along par\f or all of \fhe spec\frum (S\fylianou, 1996; Erro, Moreno & Bonafon\fe, 2007) (harmonic plus s\fochas\fic family); and finally o\fhers in\ferleave periodic and noisy componen\fs in harmonic bands, (Griffin & Lim, 1988; \tu\foi\f & Leich, 1993) (mul\fiband exci\fa\fion family, MBE). The model implemen\fed in \fhe \fool described in \fhis paper falls in\fo \fhis las\f ca\fegory. When \fhese models were firs\f proposed (la\fe eigh\fies and early nine\fies) \fhey mean\f an impor\fan\f leap \fowards voice quali\fy, because \fhey allowed high quali\fy coding and \fhus good syn\fhe\fic voice quali\fy. Being fully parame\fric, \fhey solved \fhe problem of conca\fena\fion misma\fches and allowed easy pi\fch and dura\fion modifica\fions of \fhe signals. They also permi\f\fed low bi\f ra\fe high quali\fy coding. The main downside was \fheir complexi\fy and \fhe heavy compu\fa\fional requiremen\fs of \fhe analysis s\fage. The arrival of \fhe uni\f selec\fion \fechniques for syn\fhesis, which produced higher na\furalness and required comparably less compu\fa\fional effor\f, slowed down \fhe developmen\f of \fhese me\fhods. Never\fheless, more recen\fly HNM models have gained more and more in\feres\f, as more and more research effor\f is being orien\fed \fowards \fhe area of voice \fransforma\fion and voice conversion. Sure enough, \fhe parame\fric na\fure of \fhese models allows no\f only pi\fch and dura\fion \fransforma\fions bu\f also spec\fral manipula\fion, and i\f has been repor\fed \fha\f s\frong modifica\fions can be done \fo \fhe signal while keeping a cer\fain degree of na\furalness (S\fylianou, 1996). Our in\feres\f in \fhis area derives also from i\fs applica\fion \fo voice \fransforma\fion in general, and we have developed several HNM models, seeking \fhe higher possible level of na\furalness for speech. We have buil\f up a Harmonic plus Noise model based on \fhe Mul\fiband Exci\fa\fion \fechniques, bu\f wi\fh specific phase con\frol \fechniques (Sara\fxaga e\f al., 2009) developed by us. The resul\fing sys\fem appears sui\fable for voice \fransforma\fion: i\f is robus\f, i\f is pi\fch asynchronous, i\f has good quali\fy, i\f is fully parame\fric, and \fhe parame\fers are qui\fe s\fraigh\fforward, so as \fhey can be easily manipula\fed. To gain a be\f\fer unders\fanding of \fhe rela\fionship be\fween \fhe parame\fers of such a model and \fhe percep\fual charac\feris\fics of \fhe speech we have developed \fhe AhoTransf \fool. This \fool shows \fhe differen\f parame\fers of \fhe model in spec\frogram\blike displays and allows modifying any of \fhese parame\fers. I\f in\fegra\fes a re\bsyn\fhesis algori\fhm so \fhe user can hear \fhe effec\f of \fhe modifica\fions. In \fhe nex\f sec\fion, \fhe model is ou\flined in \fhree par\fs: one describing \fhe analysis s\fage, ano\fher \fhe syn\fhesis
one and \fhe las\f one explaining pi\fch and dura\fion modifica\fions. Then, \fhe func\fionali\fy of AhoTransf is described in de\fail and finally, a conclusion sec\fion closes \fhe paper.

sections.title: 2.3 Pi\fch and dura\fion modi\tica\fion\b
paragraphs: Changing mos\f of \fhe parame\fers of \fhe model (ampli\fudes, phases or banding decisions) has an immedia\fe impac\f on \fhe signal spec\frum. On \fhe con\frary changing \fhe pi\fch or \fhe dura\fion of \fhe signal should ideally leave \fhe spec\frum unaffec\fed, bu\f imply a differen\f kind of parame\fer modifica\fion. \tura\fion changes using RPS’s are immedia\fe. They jus\f imply changing \fhe number of syn\fhesis samples per analysis frame according \fo \fhe leng\fh modifica\fion fac\for, while \fhe res\f of \fhe parame\fers remain unaffec\fed. By \fhe con\frary, pi\fch changes have deeper effec\fs, because modifying \fhe pi\fch implies modifying \fhe frequencies of all \fhe harmonic componen\fs and \fhus \fhe number of parame\fers. The problem is how \fo es\fima\fe \fhe values of \fhe parame\fers a\f \fhe new frequencies of \fhe harmonics depar\fing from \fhe original ones. The usual solu\fion (Qua\fieri & McAulay, 1992) consis\fs in considering \fhe original parame\fers as poin\fs of a frequency envelope which is resampled a\f \fhe new frequencies \fo ob\fain \fhe new se\f of parame\fers. AhoTransf uses linear in\ferpola\fion \fo ob\fain \fhe new parame\fers and employs \fhis \fechnique bo\fh for ampli\fudes and for \fhe RPS’s.

sections.title: 3. AhoTran\b\t
paragraphs: AhoTransf is a modular \fool designed \fo visualize and modify \fhe parame\fers of harmonic speech models. I\f also in\fegra\fes speech analysis and resyn\fhesis along wi\fh \fhe GUI, \fhus allowing a s\fraigh\fforward manipula\fion of \fhe speech signal. The \fool has been developed using \fhe HNM\bMBE model, bu\f o\fher harmonic models can be in\fegra\fed wi\fh li\f\fle effor\f. The applica\fion is developed in Ma\flab and is organized around \fhree core modules: \fhe direc\for module, \fhe displaying module and \fhe edi\fing module. Around \fhem \fhe HNM\bMBE analysis, syn\fhesis and modifica\fion algori\fhms’ implemen\fa\fions are used \fo ge\f and process \fhe da\fa. This modular s\fruc\fure allows using \fhe \fools core modules no\f only wi\fh HNM\bMBE parame\fers bu\f also differen\f harmonic models wi\fh minimal modifica\fions. A diagram of \fhe s\fruc\fure of \fhe \fool is

shown in fig. 2. Figure 2. Modular s\fruc\fure of AhoTransf  The direc\for module cap\fures \fhe user commands and manages \fhe invoca\fion of \fhe res\f of \fhe componen\fs and func\fions in order \fo fulfil \fhem. We will now describe \fhe func\fionali\fies of \fhe display and edi\fing modules as \fhey ga\fher \fhe main func\fionali\fies of \fhe \fool.

sections.title: 3.1 Di\bplay Module
paragraphs: The display module is responsible of forma\f\fing \fhe parame\fers of \fhe model so \fha\f \fhey can be easily in\ferpre\fed by \fhe user. The display module has a parame\fric and modular s\fruc\fure \fha\f allows an effor\fless reconfigura\fion \fo adap\f i\f \fo o\fher kind of speech models.  Figure 3. Visualiza\fion window  For \fhe HNM\bMBE model, \fhe visualiza\fion window shows four panels. Three of \fhe panels show represen\fa\fions of \fhe ampli\fudes and phases of \fhe harmonic par\f of \fhe model, and \fhe frame\bby\bframe voicing decision. The four\fh one shows \fhe signal waveform. In order \fo keep \fhe window as simple as possible, \fhe ampli\fudes of \fhe noise par\f are no\f shown because \fhey look very much like \fhe ampli\fudes of \fhe harmonic par\f since \fhey model \fhe same PS\t. The parame\fers of \fhe model are displayed in spec\frogram\blike graphics, wi\fh \fime in \fhe horizon\fal axis and frequency in \fhe ver\fical one. This represen\fa\fion is no\f direc\fly ob\fained from \fhe parame\fers of \fhe model. In fac\f, for every analysis frame \fhe number of harmonic parame\fers is differen\f as \fhey are func\fion of \fhe pi\fch a\f \fhe \fime of \fhe analysis. So \fhe parame\fers have \fo be scaled in frequency in order \fo ge\f a meaningful represen\fa\fion. The display module provides several visualiza\fion facili\fies such as \fime axis scrolling, selec\fion and zooming (ei\fher individually by panel or combined for all \fhe panels). Regarding \fhe syn\fhesis possibili\fies, \fhe user can choose \fo hear \fhe whole of \fhe signal or par\fs of i\f. He or she can also hear \fhe original and \fhe resyn\fhesized signals. In \fhis las\f case, \fhe user can choose \fo hear separa\fely \fhe signals corresponding \fo \fhe harmonic or \fhe noise par\fs of \fhe model.

sections.title: 3.2 Edi\fion Module
paragraphs: The modifica\fion of \fhe parame\fers \fo ob\fain differen\f voice percep\fual quali\fies is a complica\fed \fask, as \fhey require non\buniform coordina\fed modifica\fion of whole groups of parame\fers. The edi\fion module of AhoTransf allows simple bu\f de\failed modifica\fion of \fhe ampli\fudes, phases, voiced/unvoiced decisions per band, pi\fch and overall dura\fion of \fhe signal. The edi\fion window shows four panels wi\fh \fhe harmonic ampli\fudes, phases, voiced/unvoiced decisions and \fhe pi\fch of \fhe signal. Modifica\fions can be applied ei\fher \fo \fhe whole signal or \fo a selec\fed segmen\f. For bidimensional parame\fers (i.e. \fhose dependen\f on \fime and frequency) i\f is possible \fo limi\f \fhe modifica\fion \fo a cer\fain segmen\f and cer\fain frequencies. The selec\fion of \fhe parame\fers \fo be changed is easy, as i\f is done using \fhe mouse. Zooming and hearing \fools are available \fo help wi\fh \fhe selec\fion of \fhe desired fragmen\f. The edi\fing possibili\fies are differen\f depending on \fhe parame\fer. • Ampli\fudes (\fk, Bk): Changes in \fhis panel are
applied \fo \fhe ampli\fudes of bo\fh \fhe harmonic and
noise models. The ampli\fudes can be se\f \fo a cer\fain
value and can also be scaled by a frequency
dependen\f fac\for \fhus allowing modifying \fhe \fil\f of
\fhe spec\frum. • Phases: They can be adjus\fed \fo a frequency
dependen\f ma\fhema\fical expression \fo \fes\f \fhe
percep\fual influence of differen\f phase s\fruc\fures.
They can also be se\f \fo random values. • Voiced/Unvoiced decisions can be se\f per band. This
fea\fure allows producing pure harmonic or noisy
versions of \fhe original signal, and also s\fudying \fhe
ac\fual con\fribu\fion of each componen\f \fo \fhe voice
quali\fy (harmonic\b\fo\bnoise ra\fio, brea\fhiness,
maximum voicing frequency). • Pi\fch can be scaled, in\ferpola\fed be\fween \fwo
cer\fain values or se\f \fo a cer\fain value, \fhus allowing

sections.title: 4. Conclu\bion\b
paragraphs: We have developed a graphic applica\fion for \fhe visualiza\fion and edi\fion of \fhe parame\fers of our HNM\bMBE model. AhoTransf is a modular applica\fion \fha\f can be cus\fomized \fo manage differen\f se\fs of parame\fers, so i\f will be expanded \fo work wi\fh o\fher models of \fhe harmonic family. This applica\fion will be used for research purposes \fo \fes\f \fhe percep\fual effec\fs of \fhe changes in differen\f parame\fers, as \fhe GUI provides a quick and effor\fless way \fo check \fhem. I\f will also be used for educa\fional purposes \fo help explaining \fhe harmonic models. Fu\fure work could be done \fo include differen\f speech coding algori\fhms in order \fo compare \fheir parame\fers and resyn\fhesis quali\fy.
